Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: How Does Infrastructure Shape Equity and Well-being across the Urban-Rural Gradient?; Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; August 2019

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project funds a three day conference to be held in August, 2019 in Philadelphia, PA. The goal is to improve an understanding of the role of equity and well-being across the urban-rural gradient. The event will develop new models of knowledge development among researchers, communities, industry, practitioners, and government to understand interactions and feedback mechanisms between infrastructure and surrounding environmental, economic, and social systems. The conference focuses on the Philadelphia metropolitan region to ground the discussion because it provides a compelling site as one of the most populous, oldest, and poorest cities in the US. The conference also considers the scalability of the research frameworks and models to other cities and regions in the US and globally. This scientific research contribution thus supports NSF's mission to promote the progress of science and to advance our national welfare. In this case, the benefits will be insights to improve urban sustainability which will save lives and economic losses.

The conference assembles 40 individuals including academics (with interdisciplinary research expertise on sustainability in Philadelphia and beyond), representatives from local government, nonprofit and community organizations (environment, regional planning, education). The results will be disseminated to a broad group of stakeholders through the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission, the Franklin Institute Science Museum, Planet Philadelphia radio show and podcast, and the publication of a special issue in the Current Opinions in Environmental Sustainability

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The workshop entitled How Does Infrastructure Shape Equity and Well-being across the Urban-Rural Gradient took place on September 11th to September 13th, 2019 at Temple University.  The workshop was attended by 68 participants representing a range of disciplines, including the social, engineering, health, data and environmental sciences, and sectors, including researchers, practitioners, industry leaders, government agencies, educators, journalists, and community organizers. Workshop participants included 30 academic researchers at various stages of their careers from natural science, social science, engineering, public health, and medical fields, and the additional 38 participants were from local and state government, industries, non-profits, and community organizations.

The goal of this project was to bring together multiple stakeholders from academia, municipalities, industry, and non-profit and community organizations to discuss how infrastructure shapes equity and well-being across the urban-rural gradient for Sustainable Urban Systems (SUS) in the Philadelphia metropolitan region.

The objectives of the workshop were to:                            

  • Identify methodological challenges and data gaps and develop new conceptual frameworks and research questions for a convergence science of equity and well-being for SUS across the urban-rural gradient.                                                  
  • Identify challenges and develop new models of co-production of actionable knowledge for SUS.                                                      
  • Determine the scalability of the conceptual frameworks developed in the Philadelphia metropolitan area to other cities and regions in the US and globally.        

The workshop consisted of a combination of formal presentations, a keynote address, panel discussions, and breakout group discussions. Each day addressed one of the workshop objectives and advanced a research agenda about how infrastructure shapes equity and well-being across the urban rural gradient. The workshop concluded with a positive outlook on the future of the development of a science of equity and well-being across the urban-rural gradient. Recurring themes that we will center future work around and continue to elaborate on are:

  • How to create and evaluate models for knowledge co-production: Participants agreed that co-production of knowledge (between academic researchers, policymakers, educators, and nonprofit workers, etc.) must be a priority for developing a science of equity and well-being across the urban-rural gradient. However, much more must be done in terms of developing feasible and ethical models for this approach to research as well as methods for evaluating these models.
  • How to meaningfully prioritize equity and well-being in sustainability research and planning: Participants discussed the fact that academia has put forth several critiques of equity issues in planning but have offered few solutions. They identified a significant gap in research and planning, which is that academics and planners lack knowledge about what communities actually think about equity, infrastructure, and sustainability, which underscores the importance of co-produced knowledge.
  • How to bring analysis of health into infrastructure research: Participants discovered that there is very little research that looks at the impacts of specific infrastructures on health outcomes and proposed that this should be a key area of future research.
  • Possible re-conceptualizations of the urban-rural gradient: Participants debated the usefulness of the concept of ?urban-rural gradient? and whether the terms ?mosaic? or ?network? might be more accurate. The consensus was that urban-rural systems are in fact a key arena for future research, and therefore more thought should be put into how best to conceptualize these systems.
  • Comparative research on infrastructure systems: While the Philadelphia metropolitan area was the case study for exploring these topics, participants identified the need for comparative research across the urban-rural gradient, between different urban-rural sites, and especially between the Global North and the Global South.

Our workshop will help shape the next generation of SUS by identifying gaps and needs for a transdisciplinary framework of equity and well-being for convergence SUS. We began to conceptualize the urban-rural gradient from transdisciplinary perspectives including both scholars and practitioners. The workshop brought together scholars from across the natural sciences, engineering, and social sciences with practitioners from a wide array of policy, educational, environmental and social justice organizations. The academics included women and underrepresented groups at all stages of careers (faculty at all ranks, post-docs, and graduate students). The practitioners that served on the Organizing Committee and attended the workshop represented a diverse group in terms of gender and race. Additionally, there were representatives from environmental and social justice organizations who are members of communities that are historically disenfranchised.

The broader impacts of the workshop include: 

  • Dissemination of the outcomes to a broader group of stakeholders through the Franklin Institute Science Museum, the Delaware Valley Regional Planning Association, the Planet Philadelphia radio show and podcast, and the development of journal publications.
  • Building a transdisciplinary conceptualization of issues related to infrastructure, well-being, and equity that can serve as an initial model for broader applications in the NE region and globally.
  • Influencing policymakers to use a broader understanding of equity in their planning activities for sustainable infrastructural development.
